verses.verse: Jotham Reigns in Judah Jotham (2 Kin. 15:32-35) was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned sixteen years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Jerushah the daughter of Zadok.

And he did what was right in the sight of the LORD, according to all that his father Uzziah had done (although he did not enter the temple of the LORD). But still (2 Kin. 15:35; Ezek. 20:44; 30:13) the people acted corruptly.
He built the Upper Gate of the house of the LORD, and he built extensively on the wall of (2 Chr. 33:14; Neh. 3:26) Ophel.
Moreover he built cities in the mountains of Judah, and in the forests he built fortresses and towers.

He also fought with the king of the (2 Chr. 26:8) Ammonites and defeated them. And the people of Ammon gave him in that year one hundred talents of silver, ten thousand kors of wheat, and ten thousand of barley. The people of Ammon paid this to him in the second and third years also.
So Jotham became mighty, (2 Chr. 26:5) because he prepared his ways before the LORD his God.
Now the rest of the acts of Jotham, and all his wars and his ways, indeed they are written in the book of the kings of Israel and Judah.
He was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned sixteen years in Jerusalem.
(2 Kin. 15:38) So Jotham rested with his fathers, and they buried him in the City of David. Then (Is. 1:1; Hos. 1:1; Mic. 1:1) Ahaz his son reigned in his place.

Ahaz Reigns in Judah Ahaz (2 Kin. 16:2-4) was twenty years old when he became king, and he reigned sixteen years in Jerusalem; and he did not do what was right in the sight of the LORD, as his father David had done.
For he walked in the ways of the kings of Israel, and made (Ex. 34:17; Lev. 19:4) molded images for (Judg. 2:11) the Baals.

He burned incense in (Josh. 15:8) the Valley of the Son of Hinnom, and burned (2 Kin. 23:10) his children in the ((Lev. 18:21); 2 Kin. 16:3; 2 Chr. 33:6) fire, according to the abominations of the nations whom the LORD had ((Lev. 18:24-30)) cast out before the children of Israel.
And he sacrificed and burned incense on the high places, on the hills, and under every green tree.

Syria and Israel Defeat Judah Therefore ((Is. 10:5)) the LORD his God delivered him into the hand of the king of Syria. They (2 Kin. 16:5, 6; (2 Chr. 24:24); Is. 7:1, 17) defeated him, and carried away a great multitude of them as captives, and brought them to Damascus. Then he was also delivered into the hand of the king of Israel, who defeated him with a great slaughter.
For (2 Kin. 15:27) Pekah the son of Remaliah killed one hundred and twenty thousand in Judah in one day, all valiant men, ((2 Chr. 29:8)) because they had forsaken the LORD God of their fathers.
Zichri, a mighty man of Ephraim, killed Maaseiah the king’s son, Azrikam the officer over the house, and Elkanah who was second to the king.

And the children of Israel carried away captive of their (Deut. 28:25, 41; 2 Chr. 11:4) brethren two hundred thousand women, sons, and daughters; and they also took away much spoil from them, and brought the spoil to Samaria.

Israel Returns the Captives But a (2 Chr. 25:15) prophet of the LORD was there, whose name was Oded; and he went out before the army that came to Samaria, and said to them: “Look, (Ps. 69:26; (Is. 10:5; 47:6); Ezek. 25:12, 15; 26:2; Obad. 10; (Zech. 1:15)) because the LORD God of your fathers was angry with Judah, He has delivered them into your hand; but you have killed them in a rage that (Ezra 9:6; Rev. 18:5) reaches up to heaven.
And now you propose to force the children of Judah and Jerusalem to be your ((Lev. 25:39, 42, 43, 46)) male and female slaves; but are you not also guilty before the LORD your God?
Now hear me, therefore, and return the captives, whom you have taken captive from your brethren, (Ps. 78:49; James 2:13) for the fierce wrath of the LORD is upon you.”

Then some of the heads of the children of Ephraim, Azariah the son of Johanan, Berechiah the son of Meshillemoth, Jehizkiah the son of Shallum, and Amasa the son of Hadlai, stood up against those who came from the war,

and said to them, “You shall not bring the captives here, for we already have offended the LORD. You intend to add to our sins and to our guilt; for our guilt is great, and there is fierce wrath against Israel.”
So the armed men left the captives and the spoil before the leaders and all the assembly.

Then the men (2 Chr. 28:12) who were designated by name rose up and took the captives, and from the spoil they clothed all who were naked among them, dressed them and gave them sandals, ((Prov. 25:21, 22; Luke 6:27; Rom. 12:20)) gave them food and drink, and anointed them; and they let all the feeble ones ride on donkeys. So they brought them to their brethren at Jericho, (Deut. 34:3; Judg. 1:16) the city of palm trees. Then they returned to Samaria.
Assyria Refuses to Help Judah (2 Kin. 16:7) At the same time King Ahaz sent to the kings of Assyria to help him.
For again the (2 Chr. 21:10; Obad. 10-14) Edomites had come, attacked Judah, and carried away captives.

(2 Chr. 21:16, 17; Ezek. 16:27, 57) The Philistines also had invaded the cities of the lowland and of the South of Judah, and had taken Beth Shemesh, Aijalon, Gederoth, Sochoh with its villages, Timnah with its villages, and Gimzo with its villages; and they dwelt there.
